UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS
January 31, 1953
MEMORANDUM
TO: Graydon Ausmus
FROM: Robert B. Hudson
SUBJECT: NAEB Seminar and/or Television Program Planning Meeting
Following the meetings in New York this week, I am sure you recognize that
the newly organized Educational Television and Radio Program Center is
concerned, concurrently, with matters of staffing, philosophy and plan of
operation, the character and breadth of the service to be offered, the
interests and needs of educational television stations to be served, and
sources of creative programs internal to educational institutions.
In view of these concerns (and because so much fog has enveloped thinking
about another NAEB seminar), it occurs to me that a very practical course
of action is open to the NAEB, acting through its Advisory Committee to
the Center, whereby the Center will benefit and the NAEB will be strengthened.
My suggestion is that the NAEB propose to the Fund for Adult Education that
the $5,000 grant already appropriated for a NAEB seminar be made available
to the NAEB Advisory Committee to the Center for the purpose of holding a
planning meeting of the key television program people in those educational
institutions that appear to be most ready to produce television programs,
with or without grants-in-aid, for distribution through the Center.
In essence, such a meeting would be concerned with creative programming-
an assessment of what programs the potential educational television stations
and production units are prepared to start on now, and an estimate of their
production timetable for them. Of even greater importance would be the
assessment of what the overall job is-what kinds of programs and for what
purpose.
In getting at the what and the why of programs to be supplied to the Center,
the meeting would in effect be hammering out a program philosophy which
your Advisory Committee, in turn, could recommend to the Center. The meeting
would identify what it considers to be the interests and needs of educational
television stations, and it would clarify thinking on what should be the
character and breadth of the service of the Center to stations. There is no
doubt about the Board and the officers (yet to be selected) of the Center
welcoming advice on these points. Furthermore, the Center appears to be
looking to its NAEB Advisory Committee for advice, and I think this is the
proper time for your Committee to take initiative. I feel sure that Mr.
Fletcher, as Acting President of the Center, would be prepared to underwrite
the expenses of your Committee in planning such a meeting.
If this plan appeals to you and to your associates in the NAEB, may I suggest
that you take it up with Mr. Fletcher and Mr. Griffiths without delay.
I am listing on the attached sheet several procedural steps that may provide
a useful framework in which to consider this proposal.
